newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK stocks end cautious session with small gains.
newsitem.headline: HK stocks end cautious session with small gains.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks ended with small gains on Wednesday, after investors spent a cautious session searching for direction and awaiting fiscal 1996 results from the Henderson group due after the close, analysts said.
The Hang Seng index ended with a 12.74 point gain at 11,236.36. Turnover was HK$3.74 billion, down from HK$4.71 billion on Tuesday.
"People are still looking for direction. Not a great deal happened on the Street (overnight)," said Rory McAllister at HSBC James Capel.
Wall Street stocks ended slightly weaker on Tuesday with the Dow industrials slipping 6.66 points to 5,727.18.
Edward Chan, research director at Standard Chartered Securities, said Hong Kong stocks were likely to move sideways in the short-term following a sharp rally early in the week.
The Hang Seng index gained 187.01 points on Monday and rose 11.02 points on Tuesday.

"We have already seen a strong rebound over last few days so sentiment tends to be quite cautious. I think people expect there will be a minor (U.S.) interest rate increase either at the end of the month or next month," said Chan.
Shares in Henderson Land finished the session down HK$0.75 at HK$61.00 ahead of the release of its fiscal 1996 results.
Shares in Henderson Investment, also due to release results later on Wednesday, closed unchanged at HK$8.15 and Henderson China Holdings rose HK$0.50 to HK$17.00.
China Light & Power Co Ltd rose sharply, ending the session up HK$0.80 at HK$33.70 amid talk of a possible covered warrant issue on the stock, brokers said.
Swire Pacific shares were also boosted by talk of a covered warrant issue and closed HK$0.75 higher at HK$68.25.

Swire said the pre-sale of 48 residential units at its Island Place property development had received an "enthusiastic reponse" with 160 applications registered on Tuesday, the first day of registration.
Star Entertainment continued to surge ahead of a proposed rights issue. The stock gained HK$0.29 to close at HK$1.13.
New World Infrastructure fell HK$0.25 to HK$17.45 and Road King Infrastructure Ltd shed HK$0.20 to HK$6.20.
Brokers said investors were concerned about an oversupply of highway infrastructure related stocks, with at least two H-share issues in the sector expected in coming weeks.
